utterances: Sonya Begal(ph) seems much older than 17, as she opens up the door to her apartment.
Oh, here's my bathroom.
My kitchen is a mess right now.
I'm cleaning it because I've been working a lot.
In a few hours, she'll take the bus to her job.
When she's not working, she's studying for the GED.
She wants to become a nursing assistant.
But she worries her plans could chance if Rhode Island decides to cut off foster kids once they turn 18.
Right now, the state pays for her apartment.
You know, if they cut it, I'm going to be homeless.
I have no way to make the rent.
And I have, you know, I have to, like, have money for medical insurance, and food, and the rent.
And my DCYF worker said that basically all I'm going to have is a shelter referral.
About 850 foster care kids could become homeless or lose their health insurance if this passes.
Rhode Island is facing a $360 million budget deficit.
So the governor wants every state department to make cuts.
The Rhode Island Department of Children, Youth and Families' Patricia Martinez had to figure out how to decrease her budget by $30 million.
And what was she supposed to do -cut programs for 3-year-olds?
Unidentified Child #2: How will I get to school?
There's a subway four blocks from the house, four or five.
No more than six blocks.
At the heart is a very different vision about what works best for dealing with North Korea.
I think South Korea would prefer the kinder and gentler approach.
They don't like pointing out publicly that North Korea has large percentages of its population that suffer from something very close to starvation, huge prisons camps.
It is a deeply brutal regime, and I don't think anyone questions that.
But the South Koreans believe you have a better shot at either changing or moderating that behavior by engaging North Korea.
Where I think the United States position currently is to try to isolate them.
That's the heart of the tension, and from there many other things complicate relations.
Are there any concrete examples of how this tension has manifest itself?
Well, let me give you a specific example associated with Iraq.
For quite some time, the number three contributor of troops to the military engagement in Iraq has been South Korea; right behind Britain.

Well, on several occasions, including the State of the Union a couple of years ago, the United States has either forgotten to thank South Korea, or has not given South Korea enough credit for such a major contribution.
And as a consequence of that, there have been a lot of anxieties in South Korea that the United States is ungrateful for the contribution that South Korea has made on behalf of the alliance.
Does the U.S.
still consider South Korea a strategic ally?
I think the answer is fundamentally yes.
But there are many problems in the relationship.
I can best approximate it to a long royal marriage.
And you know how a king and queen will go out, wave to the adoring crowds from the balcony, appear to be the picture of, you know, health and vitality.
And then once that's over they will both retreat silently to their respective parts of the palace.
Both South Korea and the United States have made an assessment that they're not very close right now.
They have many strategic differences, but that the process of divorce is unacceptable.
But the process of trying to fix the relationship is also very difficult as well.

So I think in many respects, both countries go a little bit through the motions and don't address some of the fundamental problems that are at the heart of a relationship, at least in my view, has been central to a successful American strategy in Asia over the last half century.
Kurt Campbell is the senior vice president at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
A pair of NPR reporters are on the road this month crossing the country talking with people about the government.
Jeff Brady started his journey in Oregon.
Yesterday, he sent us a report from Rock Springs, Wyoming.
Andrea Seabrook began in South Carolina and she's made it all the way to South Dakota.
There she found that living the rural life doesn't mean getting away from the long arm of the government.
I pulled off on the side of a sleepy gravel road in Beresford, South Dakota, where there's a wide, low hog barn.
Rick Moran just sold his pigs for slaughter and gets a new bunch next week.
So he stands in the hog lot supervising his son, Jalin(ph), who's driving a small tractor called the skid loader, scraping pig manure from the floor.
Basically, this is his first time doing it, and I told him the three things he can't hit is my two hog feeders and the hog waterer.
Otherwise, everything else is cement.
He's pretty much indestructible.
So...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Jalin is 12 years old, too young for a driver's license, but, says his dad, the perfect age to learn to drive a tractor.
In their rural lifestyle, Moran's kids have space to run and holler.
They drive four-wheelers and build water bottle rockets, but they also work, Moran says, especially in the hog barns and during hay baling time.
If you're tall enough to see over the steering wheel, you can drive out in the alfalfa field and that's how everybody learned out here.
So that's one of the advantages out here.
You know, you get 40 acres to drive around in vs. in the city.
I don't know how you guys learn to drive, and it probably shows.
(Soundbite of laughter; tractor engine)
Moran says he feels lucky every day being out here, and it is gorgeous; open, turquoise skies, bright yellow sunflowers stick up over the grasses and chimney swifts swoop and dart chasing insects.
But if you think getting away to this rural life means getting away from the government, think again.

Moran has a long list of ways the government is involved in his life, from what crops he plants and how in order to get subsidies to how he manages wetlands and wildlife on his land and especially, Moran says, with these hog lots.
We have to follow setbacks, rules, guidelines.
You know, we need to have waste management plans.
You just don't build something anymore; you have to go through all the rules and regulations.
So the government is involved in every asset that I have out here.
Up north, outside De Smet, South Dakota, some other kids are learning to drive.
ANN POPPIN(ph) (Teacher): Now have you guys driven horses before?
OK.
Well, I'm going to explain a couple quick things about driving the wagon, and then we'll turn it over to you and you guys are going to take us right back to the barn.
OK?
And now your letters.
We got several about our story on Muslim women who wear the full face veil.
Sammy Malick(ph), an Iranian native now living in New York City, wrote, There is no education on the subject in most Muslim societies, and the women are not given a choice.
The hijab has been exploited by patriarchal societies to a cruel and inhumane degree.
Unidentified Child #2: And what about the cat?
Unidentified Man #2: (Polish spoken)
This is one of those proposals that no one takes pleasure doing.
And if it wasn't because of the financial crisis that we are facing as a state, this wouldn't be at the table.

National foster care advocates say Rhode Island's proposal is pretty unusual, especially since more than 30 states from Iowa to Illinois to California offers some type of foster care until kids' 21st birthdays.
The executive director of the Jim Casey Youth Opportunities Initiative, Gary Stangler, says it's a bad idea to assume that any 18-year-old is a full-fledged adult.
At age 18, kids are not usually even graduated from high school.

The state has been their parents legally to age 18, and I think no other parent would simply cut off their 18-year-old, even if he or she hadn't finished high school, without at least the basic supports of having a family to fall back on.
The Rhode Island governor, Donald Carcieri, says that if this budget cut passes the state legislature, the state will look at each 18-year-old foster kid and come up with a plan.
Governor Carcieri says there are so many people the state has to look after.
The premise that we went into this budget was to protect the most vulnerable - that is our seniors, as persons both young and old with disabilities.
And when you go through that, then you come down to programs and changes that you can make where, yes, there will be impacts, but you hope to minimize those.
Sonya Begal and other foster teens have been holding protests at the Rhode Island Statehouse.
They are also making other plans to live with family members, find roommates, or save money for their first and last month's rent.
For NPR News, I'm Nancy Cook in Providence.
(Soundbite of music)
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Andrea Seabrook.
It's economic common sense: when the demand for a product goes down, sellers lower their prices.
Let's say people stop driving so much.
Well, the price of a gallon of gas might drop by a dime.
Yeah, we wish.
But for some reason homeowners don't abide by that rule.
In this depressed housing market many homeowners would rather not sell at all than mark down their asking price.
Hersh Shefrin is a pioneer in the field of behavioral finance at Santa Clara University.
He joins me now to explain the thinking here.
Hello there.
Hello.
So, first, what is behavioral finance?
Behavioral finance is the study of how psychology impacts financial decision making.
